data.value: is a vector perpendicular to both
are defined by the values along the dimension
and can have sizes 1, 2 or 3. Where the size of either

is 1 or 2, the remaining components of the input vector is assumed to be zero and the cross product calculated accordingly. In cases where both input vectors have dimension 2, the z-component of the cross product is returned.
Components of the first and second vector(s).
The dimension along which the cross product will be computed. Must be available in both vectors.
Compute the cross product of two (arrays of) vectors.
Vector cross-product with 2 dimensions, returns in the perpendicular direction:
Vector cross-product with 3 dimensions but zeros at the last axis yields the same results as with 2 dimensions:
One vector with dimension 2 but coords in other positions:
Multiple vector cross-products. Note that the direction of the cross product vector is defined by the right-hand rule:

data.out:
<xarray.DataArray (time: 2, cartesian: 3)>
array([[-3,  6, -3],
       [ 3, -6,  3]])
Coordinates:
  * time       (time) int64 0 1
  * cartesian  (cartesian) <U1 'x' 'y' 'z'

data.value: Cross can be called on Datasets by converting to DataArrays and later back to a Dataset:

data.out:
<xarray.Dataset>
Dimensions:  (dim_0: 1)
Dimensions without coordinates: dim_0
Data variables:
    x        (dim_0) int64 -3
    y        (dim_0) int64 6
    z        (dim_0) int64 -3

signature.value: cross(a: 'DataArray | Variable', b: 'DataArray | Variable', *, dim: 'Hashable') -> 'DataArray | Variable'
